awd_titl_txt: Emergent Unconventional Superconductivity at Interfaces between Superconductor, Topological, and Magnetic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Computers are ubiquitous, yet typical computation methods consume enormous amounts energy, soon to reach unsustainable levels. Thus, an eminent national grand challenge is to develop a more energy efficient method with which to process information without losing computing power. This project addresses this challenge by determining the unique physical properties of unconventional superconducting materials, which could then be used to design a more powerful and energy efficient computer, referred to as a topological quantum computer. Unconventional superconductors are materials that exhibit useful zero-resistance states, but whose properties are poorly understood. The proposed work combines theoretical and experimental expertise to fabricate nanoscale superconducting devices, and investigate the different combinations of materials and electronic transport measurements that best establish and probe unconventional superconductivity. The results of the research help determine properties that may be useful in a quantum computer. The collaborative research team incorporates a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in research activities and provides a rich environment for training in nanoscale and quantum technologies. Educational aspects are further integrated through course development, research-related seminars, and outreach activities that especially target groups under-represented in physics.

Technical Abstract:
The goal of this project is to determine the symmetry and transport properties of superconductors suspected of exhibiting unconventional pairing symmetry as result of proximity coupling to topological and ferromagnetic materials. The aim is to both better understand complex superconducting systems and also to determine their potential use in electronic devices. The experimental effort consists of making phase-sensitive as well as quantum transport measurements of the hybrid topological superconductor/magnetic structures to determine the superconducting order. The experimental research is closely coordinated with a theoretical effort that uses both numerical and analytic techniques to analyze the experimental data and aid in the design of new experiments. Key expected outcomes include: determining the pairing symmetry of proximity-coupled and intrinsically superconducting topological insulators; observing if exotic excitations, possibly Majorana, exist and determining their relation to the pairing symmetry; and developing new techniques for probing unconventional superconductors, including enhanced phase-sensitive probes. The collaborative research team incorporates a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in research activities and provides a rich environment for training in nanoscale and quantum technologies. Educational aspects are further integrated through course development, research-related seminars, and outreach activities that especially target groups under-represented in physics.

por.por_cntn:
This project determined the properties of a hybrid material system -- topological insulators coupled to superconductors an in magnetic fields -- which are predicted to form the basis of a new type of powerful and energy efficient computer, referred to as a topological quantum computer. Collaborative experimental and theoretical studies were performed to create and model new types of superconductor-topological devices, to determine fundamental properties as well as suitability for computing applications. The research goals were accomplished on multiple fronts:

Intellectual merit: The major outcomes of this research were significant advances in the spectroscopy of hybrid topological-superconducting materials, leading to greater understanding of key transport properties. In particular, the conditions under which excitations relevant to quantum computation appear were constrained and clarified. Specific project outcomes include: (1) Joint experimental-theoretical publications on “Fraunhofer spectroscopy” of topological insulator-superconducting junctions, showing how magnetic fields and disorder can lead to new types of superconducting transport, (2) Developing new techniques to couple topologically-relevant relevant InSb semiconductor nanowires to superconductors, via selective-area epitaxy and non-invasive tunnel probes, (3) Determining the transport signatures of topological superconductivity in Nb-doped Bi2Se3, and unconventional superconductivity in La2-xSrxCuO4, (4) Constructing models of the interacting topological phases in superconductors and the relevant excitations in magnetic-topological superconductors, and (5) Demonstrating the effect of disorder on transport in hybrid superconductor-metal systems.

Broader Impact: The improved understanding of transport and excitations in topological superconducting systems is useful to a variety of applications, including quantum computation, superconducting sensors, MRIs, and superconducting wires for low-power applications. The tools developed to study topological superconductivity – e.g, tunnel probes, vortex dynamics on island arrays, Fraunhofer spectroscopy and inteferometric techniques – are new to 3D topological materials and can be utilized by other researchers to examine still-elusive topological properties. Results from this research were broadly disseminated: 14 peer-reviewed papers, mostly in top journals, were published based on work from this grant. In addition, the PIs gave many research talks on this topic, participated in workshops, and published review papers. The students and postdocs involved in this project were all trained in advanced fabrication and measurement techniques, especially relevant to training a workforce for future quantum technologies. Six PhD students completed their dissertations based on results from this grant, and all of the students are now working in industry or academia on technology related to their graduate training. Further, the researchers included a significant fraction of people under-represented in physics and materials research. The PIs also engaged in significant outreach activities, such as recruiting programs, and talks to teachers, students, and to communities traditionally under-represented in physics.
